title: 111_hr2134
content: The Act may be cited as the "Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission Act of 2009". Congress finds that in 2008, there were millions of users of marijuana, cocaine, methamphetamine, and heroin in the United States. The majority of cocaine and heroin in the US originates from Andean countries and Colombia and Mexico, respectively, leading to violence and corruption in those regions. Additionally, drug trafficking in Central America, Mexico, Venezuela, and other Caribbean countries contributes to instability. Drug trafficking in Central America, Mexico, Venezuela, Ecuador, Haiti, and other Caribbean countries poses a significant threat to local and national security, as well as to United States interests. Drug-related violence is increasing in Mexico, with a significant number of deaths reported in 2008. Organized criminal networks in Mexico are also involved in trafficking women and girls for commercial sexual exploitation in the United States. Organized criminal networks in Mexico traffic women and girls into the United States for sexual exploitation. Extremist groups like FARC and Hezbollah use drug trafficking to fund terrorist activities. US counternarcotics assistance to Latin America and the Caribbean from 1980-2008 totaled $11.3 billion. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission is established to review and evaluate US policies on illicit drug supply reduction and interdiction in the Western Hemisphere. Its purpose is to identify policy options to improve counternarcotics efforts both domestically and internationally. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will review US policies on illicit drug supply reduction, interdiction, and demand reduction. It will assess international drug control policies, interdiction efforts, crop eradication programs, and economic development alternatives. The impact of various initiatives in curbing drug production and trafficking will be evaluated. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will assess technology deployment against drug cartels, curb chemical precursor trafficking, evaluate US drug certification process, analyze population's drug demand, review prevention and treatment programs, and study drivers of drug consumption in the US. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will evaluate the effectiveness of treating individuals addicted to illicit drugs, recommend improvements in US drug policies, support efforts to reduce drug supply and demand in other countries, and assess the indicators of success in US illicit drug control policy. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will consult with various stakeholders to assess the effectiveness of US illicit drug control policy and recommend changes to increase effectiveness. A report will be submitted within 12 months of the Commission's first meeting. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will submit a report to relevant committees and officials within 12 months of its first meeting. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will submit a report to relevant committees and officials within 12 months of its first meeting, including detailed recommendations, findings, and conclusions. The report will also include summaries of input and recommendations from consulted leaders and organizations, and will be made available to the public. SEC. 6. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of ten members appointed by various leaders, excluding current government officials. Each member serves for the Commission's duration, with vacancies filled promptly. Appointments must be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission, consisting of ten members appointed by various leaders, must appoint members within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Within 60 days, the Commission will hold an initial meeting to select a Chairperson and develop a schedule for the review and report required. Six members constitute a quorum, and members will receive travel expenses in accordance with regulations. The Commission, consisting of ten members appointed by various leaders, must appoint members within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Within 60 days, the Commission will hold an initial meeting to select a Chairperson and develop a schedule for the review and report required. Six members constitute a quorum, and members will receive travel expenses in accordance with regulations. SEC. 7. POWERS. The Commission will meet as needed, hold hearings, and have access to necessary resources from various government agencies to carry out its duties. The Chairperson will make written requests for access when required. The Commission has access to resources from government agencies, including office space provided by the General Services Administration. They can use the United States mails and enter into contracts for necessary activities. The Commission can enter contracts with various entities for necessary activities, but these agreements cannot extend beyond the Commission's termination date. SEC. 8. STAFF. The Commission shall have an Executive Director who can appoint necessary staff at a pay rate not exceeding level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Commission may appoint additional personnel without following standard government hiring procedures, with pay rates not exceeding those of the General Schedule. The Executive Director of the Commission can procure temporary services and detail government employees to assist in carrying out duties without affecting their civil service status or privileges. Authorization of $2,000,000 for the Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission without fiscal year limitation. Commission terminates 60 days after report submission to Congress.
